evidence.excerpt: Deleted in its entirety.
evidence.reasoning: Risk table 8.1 correctly identifies 'One-sided, unlimited exposure contradicts Art. 10 caps.' Recommends DELETE. Amendment removes the unlimited liability clause entirely - the most direct and effective fix for this critical T1 issue.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Deleted in its entirety.
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Deleted in its entirety.

evidence.excerpt: NOTHING IN THIS AGREEMENT SHALL BE CONSTRUED TO DISCLAIM WARRANTIES THAT THE SOFTWARE WILL NOT INFRINGE THE INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS OF THIRD PARTIES
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies broad disclaimer as 'unacceptable for SaaS.' Amendment preserves critical non-infringement warranty while allowing other permissible disclaimers - directly addresses GT concern about statutory protections.
evidence.judge_reasoning: NOTHING IN THIS AGREEMENT SHALL BE CONSTRUED TO DISCLAIM WARRANTIES THAT THE SOFTWARE WILL NOT INFRINGE THE INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS OF THIRD PARTIES
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: NOTHING IN THIS AGREEMENT SHALL BE CONSTRUED TO DISCLAIM WARRANTIES THAT THE SOFTWARE WILL NOT INFRINGE THE INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS OF THIRD PARTIES

evidence.excerpt: EXCEPT FOR LIABILITY ARISING FROM EITHER PARTY'S BREACH OF CONFIDENTIALITY, DATA SECURITY OBLIGATIONS, OR INFRINGEMENT OF THE OTHER PARTY'S INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS, IN NO EVENT SHALL EITHER PARTY BE LIABLE
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'Asymmetric—protects Licensor only'. Amendment makes exclusion mutual with appropriate carve-outs for confidentiality, data security, and IP - fully addresses GT concern about one-sided protection.
evidence.judge_reasoning: EXCEPT FOR LIABILITY ARISING FROM EITHER PARTY'S BREACH OF CONFIDENTIALITY, DATA SECURITY OBLIGATIONS, OR INFRINGEMENT OF THE OTHER PARTY'S INTELLECTUAL PROPERTY RIGHTS, IN NO EVENT SHALL EITHER PARTY BE LIABLE

evidence.excerpt: THE TOTAL LIABILITY OF EITHER PARTY... SHALL NOT EXCEED THE GREATER OF (i) TWO (2) TIMES THE FEES PAID OR PAYABLE... OR (ii) TWO MILLION UNITED STATES DOLLARS (US$2,000,000)
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies cap as 'Low & one-sided'. Amendment raises to 2x fees OR $2M floor, makes mutual, and adds carve-outs - comprehensive fix addressing all GT key elements.
evidence.judge_reasoning: THE TOTAL LIABILITY OF EITHER PARTY... SHALL NOT EXCEED THE GREATER OF (i) TWO (2) TIMES THE FEES PAID OR PAYABLE... OR (ii) TWO MILLION UNITED STATES DOLLARS (US$2,000,000)
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: THE TOTAL LIABILITY OF EITHER PARTY... SHALL NOT EXCEED THE GREATER OF (i) TWO (2) TIMES THE FEES PAID OR PAYABLE... OR (ii) TWO MILLION UNITED STATES DOLLARS (US$2,000,000)

evidence.excerpt: Neither Party may assign this Agreement without the prior written consent of the other Party, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld, except that either Party may assign... (a) to an Affiliate, or (b) in connection with a merger, acquisition, or sale
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'Licensor free to assign; Licensee restricted.' Amendment makes mutual with M&A and affiliate exceptions - directly addresses GT concern about hostile provider risk.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Neither Party may assign this Agreement without the prior written consent of the other Party, such consent not to be unreasonably withheld, except that either Party may assign... (a) to an Affiliate, or (b) in connection with a merger, acquisition, or sale

evidence.reasoning: Risk table 9.1 marked ✅ 'Covers IP infringement; Licensee protected' with recommended action ADD. However, no proposed redline expands Licensor indemnification to cover data breach, negligence, or misconduct as GT expects. The expansion recommendation is acknowledged but not implemented.

gt_evaluations.issue: Narrow Indemnification - No Licensee Protection Defined

evidence.excerpt: no less stringent than those required by ISO/IEC 27001 and SOC 2 Type II standards... Licensor shall provide Licensee with an annual SOC 2 Type II report upon request
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'Reasonable safeguards too vague; no reference to industry standards.' Amendment adds specific ISO 27001/SOC 2 standards and annual audit reporting - addresses all GT key elements including audit transparency.
evidence.judge_reasoning: no less stringent than those required by ISO/IEC 27001 and SOC 2 Type II standards... Licensor shall provide Licensee with an annual SOC 2 Type II report upon request
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: no less stringent than those required by ISO/IEC 27001 and SOC 2 Type II standards... Licensor shall provide Licensee with an annual SOC 2 Type II report upon request

evidence.excerpt: Licensor shall, upon Licensee's request made within sixty (60) days following termination, provide Licensee with a complete export of Licensee Data in industry-standard format at no additional charge
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies missing data export 'jeopardizes business continuity.' Amendment adds 60-day data export window in standard format at no cost - directly addresses GT concern about data loss on termination.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Licensor shall, upon Licensee's request made within sixty (60) days following termination, provide Licensee with a complete export of Licensee Data in industry-standard format at no additional charge
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Licensor shall, upon Licensee's request made within sixty (60) days following termination, provide Licensee with a complete export of Licensee Data in industry-standard format at no additional charge

evidence.excerpt: transferable to Licensee's Affiliates and successors in connection with a merger, acquisition, or corporate reorganisation, and sublicensable to third-party service providers solely to perform services for Licensee or its Affiliates
evidence.reasoning: Risk table notes 2.1 'Non-transferable, non-sublicensable—prevents use by Affiliates.' Amendment adds affiliate transfer and service provider sublicensing - directly addresses GT concern about corporate flexibility.
evidence.judge_reasoning: transferable to Licensee's Affiliates and successors in connection with a merger, acquisition, or corporate reorganisation, and sublicensable to third-party service providers solely to perform services for Licensee or its Affiliates

evidence.excerpt: Subscription Fees shall be invoiced monthly in arrears
evidence.reasoning: Risk table notes annual advance payment 'Front-loads cash flow & risk for Licensee.' Amendment changes to monthly in arrears - directly addresses GT concern about payment timing and cash flow impact.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Subscription Fees shall be invoiced monthly in arrears
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Subscription Fees shall be invoiced monthly in arrears

evidence.excerpt: Any undisputed amounts not paid when due shall bear interest at the rate of the lesser of one percent (1.0%) per month or the maximum rate permitted by applicable law
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'Effective 18% APR—exceeds typical commercial rates.' Amendment reduces to 1% monthly and applies only to undisputed amounts - addresses GT concern about high rate.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Any undisputed amounts not paid when due shall bear interest at the rate of the lesser of one percent (1.0%) per month or the maximum rate permitted by applicable law
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Any undisputed amounts not paid when due shall bear interest at the rate of the lesser of one percent (1.0%) per month or the maximum rate permitted by applicable law

evidence.excerpt: If monthly availability falls below 99.5%, Licensee shall receive a service credit equal to 5% of the monthly Subscription Fees for each 0.1% decrement below the target, up to 100% of the monthly fee
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'No service credits for SLA breach.' Amendment adds tiered service credit formula with clear measurement - fully addresses GT concern about lack of financial remedy.
evidence.judge_reasoning: If monthly availability falls below 99.5%, Licensee shall receive a service credit equal to 5% of the monthly Subscription Fees for each 0.1% decrement below the target, up to 100% of the monthly fee
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: If monthly availability falls below 99.5%, Licensee shall receive a service credit equal to 5% of the monthly Subscription Fees for each 0.1% decrement below the target, up to 100% of the monthly fee

evidence.excerpt: 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for Severity 1 incidents, and during 9:00 AM–5:00 PM Pacific Time, Monday through Friday, for all other incidents
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'business hours PT only; Licensee may operate globally 24/7.' Amendment adds 24/7 support for Severity 1 - directly addresses GT emergency support concern.
evidence.judge_reasoning: 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for Severity 1 incidents, and during 9:00 AM–5:00 PM Pacific Time, Monday through Friday, for all other incidents
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for Severity 1 incidents, and during 9:00 AM–5:00 PM Pacific Time, Monday through Friday, for all other incidents

evidence.excerpt: Licensee hereby grants Licensor a royalty-free, non-exclusive, irrevocable licence to use and incorporate Feedback into the Software. All underlying business processes, data, or know-how disclosed by Licensee shall remain the exclusive property of Licensee
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies feedback ownership 'Transfers all ownership... without compensation.' Amendment changes to non-exclusive license and preserves Licensee's business processes - addresses ownership concern.
evidence.judge_reasoning: Licensee hereby grants Licensor a royalty-free, non-exclusive, irrevocable licence to use and incorporate Feedback into the Software. All underlying business processes, data, or know-how disclosed by Licensee shall remain the exclusive property of Licensee

evidence.excerpt: the Agreement may be renewed for additional one (1) year periods only upon mutual written agreement of the Parties executed at least thirty (30) days prior to the end of the then-current term
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'Auto-renews unless Licensee acts; could cause unwanted cost.' Amendment changes to mutual written agreement for renewal - eliminates passive renewal risk entirely.
evidence.judge_reasoning: the Agreement may be renewed for additional one (1) year periods only upon mutual written agreement of the Parties executed at least thirty (30) days prior to the end of the then-current term
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: the Agreement may be renewed for additional one (1) year periods only upon mutual written agreement of the Parties executed at least thirty (30) days prior to the end of the then-current term

evidence.excerpt: except where such third party is providing outsourced services exclusively for Licensee or its Affiliates pursuant to a written agreement that imposes confidentiality obligations
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies blanket prohibition 'conflicts with outsourcing & shared-service models.' Amendment adds carve-out for outsourced services with confidentiality - addresses operational need.
evidence.judge_reasoning: except where such third party is providing outsourced services exclusively for Licensee or its Affiliates pursuant to a written agreement that imposes confidentiality obligations
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: except where such third party is providing outsourced services exclusively for Licensee or its Affiliates pursuant to a written agreement that imposes confidentiality obligations

evidence.excerpt: the Parties shall execute and attach as Exhibit A to this Agreement a Data Processing Agreement ('DPA')... which shall automatically take effect upon the Effective Date and shall prevail over any conflicting provision
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'Separate DPA not yet executed; risk of GDPR/CCPA non-compliance.' Amendment makes DPA integral exhibit with automatic effect - ensures no compliance gap.
evidence.judge_reasoning: the Parties shall execute and attach as Exhibit A to this Agreement a Data Processing Agreement ('DPA')... which shall automatically take effect upon the Effective Date and shall prevail over any conflicting provision
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: the Parties shall execute and attach as Exhibit A to this Agreement a Data Processing Agreement ('DPA')... which shall automatically take effect upon the Effective Date and shall prevail over any conflicting provision

evidence.excerpt: If Licensor is unable to correct the non-conformity within thirty (30) days of written notice, Licensee may terminate the affected Subscription and receive a pro-rata refund of all prepaid fees
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies remedy 'limited to commercially reasonable efforts; no refund right.' Amendment adds 30-day cure period then termination + pro-rata refund - provides meaningful economic recourse.
evidence.judge_reasoning: If Licensor is unable to correct the non-conformity within thirty (30) days of written notice, Licensee may terminate the affected Subscription and receive a pro-rata refund of all prepaid fees

evidence.excerpt: The provisions of Articles 5 (Data Security and Privacy), 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11.4 (Data Return), and 12 shall survive
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies survival 'Does not list data-return, security & assignment provisions.' Amendment adds Article 5 and 11.4 specifically - addresses GT concern about post-termination protection.
evidence.judge_reasoning: The provisions of Articles 5 (Data Security and Privacy), 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11.4 (Data Return), and 12 shall survive
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: The provisions of Articles 5 (Data Security and Privacy), 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11.4 (Data Return), and 12 shall survive

evidence.excerpt: annual SOC 2 Type II report upon request
evidence.reasoning: Partial detection: 5.1 amendment requires annual SOC 2 report on request, which provides audit transparency. However, doesn't add a full independent audit right for Licensee as GT expects - report-only approach is less comprehensive.
evidence.judge_reasoning: annual SOC 2 Type II report upon request
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: annual SOC 2 Type II report upon request

evidence.reasoning: No business continuity provisions mentioned anywhere. No RTO/RPO requirements, disaster recovery provisions, or redundancy commitments proposed despite GT flagging this as material gap.

evidence.excerpt: Neither Party shall be liable for any failure or delay in performance... to the extent caused by acts of God, earthquake, flood, pandemic, terrorism, civil unrest, or other events beyond the reasonable control of the affected Party
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies missing force majeure 'leaves parties exposed to uncontrollable events.' Amendment adds comprehensive FM clause with notification and mitigation obligations.

evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: Neither Party shall be liable for any failure or delay in performance... to the extent caused by acts of God, earthquake, flood, pandemic, terrorism, civil unrest, or other events beyond the reasonable control of the affected Party

evidence.reasoning: No insurance requirements mentioned anywhere. No CGL, Cyber, E&O insurance or certificate requirements proposed despite GT flagging this as missing.

evidence.excerpt: (i) is irreversibly de-identified in accordance with NIST or equivalent standards, (ii) cannot reasonably be re-identified, and (iii) does not identify Licensee or any individual
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'No obligation to anonymize irreversibly; no opt-out.' Amendment adds NIST-standard de-identification and re-identification prohibition - fully addresses GT concern.

evidence.excerpt: The arbitration shall be conducted virtually or, at Licensee's election, in the state or country of Licensee's principal place of business
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'Travel cost & venue burden.' Amendment allows virtual or Licensee's location - reduces burden though doesn't add explicit mediation step.
evidence.judge_reasoning: The arbitration shall be conducted virtually or, at Licensee's election, in the state or country of Licensee's principal place of business
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: The arbitration shall be conducted virtually or, at Licensee's election, in the state or country of Licensee's principal place of business

evidence.excerpt: at least seven (7) days' prior notice... schedule such maintenance outside 22:00–06:00 Pacific Time where commercially feasible, and limit each maintenance window to four (4) hours
evidence.reasoning: Risk table correctly identifies 'No cap on duration/frequency; could erode uptime.' Amendment extends notice to 7 days, limits windows to 4 hours, and specifies off-peak timing - comprehensive fix.
evidence.judge_reasoning: at least seven (7) days' prior notice... schedule such maintenance outside 22:00–06:00 Pacific Time where commercially feasible, and limit each maintenance window to four (4) hours
evidence.proposed_revision_excerpt: at least seven (7) days' prior notice... schedule such maintenance outside 22:00–06:00 Pacific Time where commercially feasible, and limit each maintenance window to four (4) hours

additional_issues.notes: No express inclusion of Licensee’s Affiliates and external consultants who routinely need access; could restrict normal operations.
Marking standard absent; may create disputes over what is confidential.
No obligation to deploy critical patches within specific timeframes.
Blanket prohibition on “use for benefit of any third party” conflicts with outsourcing & shared-service models.
Some Licensee entities require 60-day terms.
No service credits for SLA breach; exclusions broad.
9-5 PT only; Licensee may operate globally 24/7.
No cap on duration/ frequency; could erode uptime.
“Reasonable safeguards” too vague; no reference to industry standards (ISO 27001, SOC 2).
Separate DPA not yet executed; risk of GDPR/CCPA non-compliance.
No obligation to anonymize “irreversibly”; no opt-out.
No survival period stated; obligations may lapse.
Remedy limited to “commercially reasonable efforts”; no refund right.
No opt-in; Beta may be auto-enabled & affect production.
Auto-renews unless Licensee acts; could cause unwanted cost.
No data extraction/transition assistance; jeopardizes business continuity.
May be acceptable, but Licensee may prefer home jurisdiction.
Travel cost & venue burden if Licensee elsewhere.
Does not list data-return, security & assignment provisions.

Expanding the definition ensures that Licensee’s corporate group and outsourced partners can lawfully access the Software without breaching the Agreement, reflecting common SaaS usage models and avoid

Removes ambiguity over marking requirements and prevents inadvertent loss of protection where information is disclosed orally or electronically without a legend, thereby safeguarding Licensee’s sensit
Adds measurable commitment ensuring timely remediation of security issues, protecting Licensee’s data integrity. Position after existing Section 1.9.
Aligns the license with typical enterprise requirements, avoiding renegotiation during corporate events and enabling operational outsourcing while maintaining Licensor’s control over scope.
Preserves Licensor’s intent to prevent resale while permitting legitimate shared-service arrangements common in modern IT operations.
Aligns cash-flow with consumption, reduces pre-payment risk for Licensee, and incentivises Licensor to maintain service quality.
Provides moderate extension consistent with many global procurement policies, without materially impacting Licensor’s cash cycle.
Lowers potential interest liability to commercially reasonable levels and confines charges to undisputed sums.
Prevents double taxation scenarios and aligns with cross-border tax norms.
Introduces financial consequence for SLA breach, incentivising performance; place immediately after current Section 4.1.
Reflects mission-critical nature of SaaS; ensures prompt assistance regardless of time zone.
Reduces disruption and gives Licensee time to prepare.
Provides objective benchmark and audit transparency vital for regulatory compliance.
Ensures no gap between go-live and compliance obligations, reducing regulatory risk.
Prevents unintended transfer of Licensee IP and preserves value of internal know-how.
Tightens anonymisation requirement, mitigating privacy and competitive risks.
Establishes definitive survival period, ensuring long-term protection without ambiguity.
Clause is one-sided, conflicts with Art. 10 limitations, and exposes Licensee to unbounded risk; deletion restores balance.
Provides meaningful economic recourse, incentivising timely remediation.
Retains core disclaimers but preserves critical non-infringement warranty.
Ensures Licensee controls exposure to unstable code, protecting production workloads.
Makes disclaimer mutual and carves-out high-risk events to ensure adequate protection and deterrence.
Establishes balanced, commercially reasonable exposure for both parties.
Eliminates passive renewal risk and aligns renewal with budget planning cycles.
Provides orderly transition and preserves business data continuity.
Aligns forum with Licensee’s domicile, reducing litigation costs and uncertainty.
Removes travel burden and provides flexibility.
Establishes reciprocity and operational flexibility during corporate changes.
Ensures critical data security and transition rights endure post-termination.
Protects both parties from liability for events outside their control; place as new Article 13 preceding Signature Page, renumbering subsequent provisions accordingly.
Completes SLA remedy mechanics; insert immediately after new Section 4.1.1.
Ensures business continuity and mitigates lock-in risk; position after Section 11.4.
